0.text:
The world is a dangerous place but, depending
on where you’re from, tha dangers you face

7.text:
can be very different. Obviously a kid from
war-torn Iraq is going to be wary of completely

13.text:
different things to a child from the wilds
of Canada; bombs versus bears, glaring sun

19.text:
versus metres of snow. So, please fasten your
seatbelt, put on your hard hat, sit down and

25.text:
take your tablets and let’s look at just
a few of the ways that the world is trying

29.text:
to kill you.
With all the talk of driverless cars and Uber,

37.text:
as well as ingenious safety systems like automatic
breaking, it’s easy to forget that driving

42.text:
can actually be a pretty dangerous activity.
So what is the worst place to hop behind the

49.text:
wheel?
Right now, it’s Iran, with a rate of about

53.text:
44 per 100,000 people dying each year on the
roads. That’s almost 15 times the rate in

60.text:
the UK, which is the third safest place to
drive in the world, only beaten by Sweden

65.text:
and Micronesia.
However, countries like Libya and Iraq are

70.text:
also high on the list of the most dangerous
places to drive, which is understandable since

74.text:
the instability in those regions means there
is no real policing of the roads. Also, the

80.text:
condition of the tarmac is probably pretty
awful. War has an annoying tendency to make

85.text:
a big mess of everything.
But there is no war in Iran, so what is the

91.text:
reason behind their dangerous driving?
One main factor is actually the country’s

97.text:
most popular car; the Kia Pride, made by Saipa.
It accounts for 40% of cars on the road and

106.text:
is described by police as a “death coach”
and they’ve even asked for its production

112.text:
to be halted. The government has also waded
in and one official, Mohammad Reza Mamdouhi,

118.text:
described it as being “detrimental to the
mental health of those who are easily agitated”.

124.text:
As slogans go, I’ve heard better.
BMW - The Ultimate Driving Machine

130.text:
Jaguar – Born to Perform
The Kia Pride – Putting the mental in detrimental

136.text:
To be fair, it’s not quite as bad as the
old Volkswagen advert – Relieves Gas Pain.

141.text:
Even Iran’s neighbours are scared of The
Pride. Photos of a few dozen new models lined

145.text:
up at the border prompted one Iraqi journalist
to joke that the question for Iraqis was “whether

153.text:
the Pride is more dangerous than Daesh (ISIS)”
You might be thinking; if it’s so awful,

159.text:
why does everyone drive it? Well that’s
largely down to the international sanctions

165.text:
that have been put on Iran over its nuclear
weapons programme. They don’t get a lot

170.text:
of foreign imports. So the new nuclear treaty
that has been signed recently will hopefully

176.text:
open up the trade of vehicles, much to the
relief of the locals. I’m pretty sure some

181.text:
of them would have rather braved nuclear winter,
than get in the ironically named Pride once

186.text:
again.
For those people trying to go on a trip without

190.text:
a car, there is always the chemical option.
The world takes a lot of drugs. To give you

197.text:
some idea, so far this year, the world has
spent $120 billion dollars on illegal substances,

204.text:
and it’s only April. What’s more, that
doesn’t include the other billions from

209.text:
prescription drugs, which are abused constantly.
The most drug related deaths per capita are

215.text:
found in Iceland, which may surprise you,
at a rate of about 21 people per 100,000.

222.text:
A lot of the other northern European countries
are high on the list too, Finland and Estonia

227.text:
for example. We suspect those long winters,
with month after month of darkness, can really

233.text:
take a toll on your mood so it makes sense
you might want a bit of escapism. Iceland

239.text:
also has the highest percentage of marijuana
users, with almost 20% of the population estimated

246.text:
to take it regularly.
Scotland leads the world for cocaine usage,

251.text:
at 2.5% of the population, which is maybe
why tourists have such a hard time understanding

256.text:
what they’re saying. And, surprisingly,
Australia is the world’s leading user of

262.text:
ecstasy, with about 3% of the country taking
it. You would have thought permanent sunshine

267.text:
and beaches would be enough, but apparently
not.

270.text:
In the US, which is very high on the list
of drug related death nations, the notorious

275.text:
War on Drugs is generally believed to have
failed. John Ehrlichman, one of Richard Nixon’s

281.text:
lead advisors, has admitted that the Comprehensive
Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1971,

288.text:
that was the real start of the war on drugs,
was really a policy tool to go after anti-war

294.text:
protesters and black communities, since they
were the biggest political threat to Nixon

299.text:
at the time.
Drug legalisation is beginning to appear around

302.text:
the world, now that governments can look at
the data provided by pioneering programs in

307.text:
countries such as the Netherlands, Portugal
and Mexico. Cannabis legalisation in the states

312.text:
seems to be going smoothly and cannabis legal
states had massive revenues of $5.4 billion

318.text:
in 2015, and they’re thought to rise again
to $6.7 billion this year. Colorado alone

325.text:
generates over $10 million in tax a month
for its state government. That’s the power

331.text:
of going green.
But, overdose is not the only way drugs can

336.text:
damage a country. If you want to see some
of its secondary effects then we need to look

341.text:
at a different death rate.
The Central American country El Salvador is

346.text:
the murder capital of the world, having overtaken
Honduras in 2015. Almost 1 in every 1000 people

356.text:
are killed every year in El Salvador. 2015
was such a bad year that it’s believed one

362.text:
person was killed per hour. That makes El
Salvador 20 times deadlier than the US and

370.text:
90 times deadlier than the UK.
Drugs play a big role since this is what provides

375.text:
an income for the viscous gangs that terrorise
the country. Some drugs, mainly cocaine, pass

381.text:
through from South America on their way up
to Mexico and the US. The drugs that are sold

387.text:
in El Salvador are the cheaper form, crack
cocaine. It also has the world’s highest

392.text:
amphetamine usage per capita.
El Salvador had a brutal 12 year civil war

398.text:
from 1980 to 1992 and it left the country
in tatters. Since that time, two main gangs

406.text:
began to establish themselves. Mara Salvatrucha
(MS-13) and Barrio 18; both gangs actually

414.text:
started out in Los Angeles, MS-13 in the 80s
and Barrio 18 as early as the 60s. But they

422.text:
both spread down into Central America and
are now the 2 most powerful groups in El Salvador.

428.text:
They are both highly organised and have very
strict codes of conduct for their members.

434.text:
They often have full body and face tattoos,
with the numbers 13 and 18 featuring heavily,

440.text:
depending on which side they’re on. And
like the hazard sign on a bottle of poison,

444.text:
those marking are a very real warning, they
are brutal. In August of 2015 the government

451.text:
tried to enforce yet another crack down on
the gangs and they responded by executing

457.text:
a dozen bus drivers, just to turn the city
into chaos. The whole month was a blood bath,

463.text:
with over 900 murders, 52 on just one day.
Surprisingly, the country still gets almost

470.text:
1.5 million tourists a year. A good deal is
a good deal, I guess, just remember to learn

476.text:
your gang greetings, you never know when they
might come in handy, no pun intended.

482.text:
Okay, now if we forget about human killers
for a moment, where do you think you are most

486.text:
likely to be slain by one of our animal kin?
Let me try and read your mind…I bet most

492.text:
of you are thinking… Australia? Right?
Well, I see why you would think that. It seems

496.text:
like everything is out to get you; spiders
in your shoes, snakes in your car, sharks

501.text:
under your surfboard, crocodiles in your pool,
ostriches and kangaroos just generally hanging

506.text:
about, looking menacing. But, although these
dangers are real, the actual death rate is

512.text:
surprisingly low. This is probably due to
good access to medical care and a general

517.text:
awareness of how to deal with these creatures.
Finding the deadliest animal country is actually

523.text:
pretty tricky but it looks like it could be
Nigeria. I’d better point out that we have

529.text:
discounted mosquitos and tsetse flies as killers
here, since although they do spread a huge

535.text:
amount of deadly disease; they themselves
are not the actual killers.

540.text:
So that leaves us with our next most lethal
group; snakes. Part of the problem is that

546.text:
in many countries, people don’t head to
hospital after being bitten, choosing local

551.text:
healers instead, so no data is collected.
In Nigeria, under 10% of bitees, not sure

559.text:
if that’s a word… go to hospital, possibly
accounting for its very high death rate from

564.text:
snake bites of 14 people per 100,000.
To make matters worse, Nigeria has a shortage

571.text:
of antivenom thanks to distribution issues,
costs, and a lack of good education in rural

577.text:
areas. The anitvenoms are pretty effective,
reducing the mortality rate by 70-90%, so

584.text:
the government are working on improving access
across the country.

588.text:
If you escape the snake, there’s a long
line of other creatures waiting to step up.

593.text:
And the largest is the water horse, or Hippopotamus.
Hippos take out almost 3,000 people a year

600.text:
globally, being very aggressive and highly
territorial. At least in Africa, people are

607.text:
aware of the dangers, but they are part of
a very peculiar story in South America.

612.text:
The notorious Columbian drug dealer, Pablo
Escobar, imported a wide range of animals

617.text:
for his zoo, which he made free to the public.
But when his empire crumbled, the animals

624.text:
were turned loose and hippos have thrived
in their new environment, maturing much earlier

630.text:
than their African counterparts. The locals
still see them as cute and friendly but it’s

635.text:
all fun and games until one of them bites
your face off.

638.text:
A final word on biting. For any of you worried
about shark attack, here’s a reassuring

643.text:
thought, you’re statistically much more
likely to get bitten by Luis Suarez than a

648.text:
shark.
Now we turn to matters of the heart. But put

652.text:
down the flowers, and definitely throw away
those fatty chocolates, because we’re talking

657.text:
about cardiovascular disease.
This is by far the world’s biggest killer,

662.text:
with over 1 in 10 deaths being down to a bad
ticker. And who leads the world as the land

669.text:
of the broken hearted? It’s the ex-soviet
nation of Turkmenistan. The country sits on

675.text:
top of Iran, like a cat wrapped around its
shoulders, but where Iran has a reasonable

679.text:
healthcare system, Turkmenistan is down in
the bottom 20% of the world, according to

685.text:
a World Health Organisation report from 2000.
So, it’s more of a Garfield than a Puss

691.text:
in Boots.
Poor diet is another contributing factor.

695.text:
The Turkmen diet consists of dishes such as
Plov, a dish made with rice and often the

700.text:
very fatty mutton. Then there are skewers
of meats like mutton and pork, called Shashlyk,

706.text:
as well as dumplings called Manti. And to
quench their thirst? Then you want to grab

712.text:
a delicious glass of Chal, a sour white sparkling
beverage, made from fermented camel milk.

719.text:
Mmm, I think I’d rather have a heart attack.
So, do what you’re told, and eat up all

726.text:
your vegetables, or you’ll get sent to your
room, which isn’t exactly the worst punishment

731.text:
in the world.
One punishment that is thankfully disappearing,

736.text:
although rather slowly, is the Death Penalty.
Right now, 94 countries have a legal death

743.text:
penalty, but only 37 actively execute people.
Of these 37, two are in the Americas, 11 in

750.text:
Africa, 23 in Asia, and only Belarus in Europe.
In most cases, the punishment is reserved

757.text:
for violent crimes, terrorism, and drug trafficking.
But in a few select countries the penalty

763.text:
also sadly applies for adultery, apostasy
(meaning to abandon your religion) and homosexuality.

771.text:
It’s not common but there have been executions
for all of these within the last 5 years.

777.text:
Come on world, we’re better than that, aren’t
we?

781.text:
Equatorial Guinea is currently the world leader
per capita, with 11.56 people executed per

789.text:
million, leading 3.70 per million in Iran,
in second place. But it is definitely China

797.text:
who has the itchiest trigger finger since
their total each year easily matches that

803.text:
of the rest of the world combined. In the
early 2000s, the number was up around 12,000

810.text:
people a year but it has now come down to
around 2000.

815.text:
The difference in attitude to capital punishment
is not a new thing. The first country to remove

819.text:
it from their law was Venezuela, all the way
back in 1863. Since 1989, at least one country

827.text:
per year has moved to abolish it, with Fiji
and Suriname being the last two, in 2015.

834.text:
When it comes to last meals, a study in the
US showed that fried chicken was probably

840.text:
the most common request. One man, Philip Workman,
asked that his last meal be a vegetarian pizza

847.text:
but rather than giving it to him, they should
give it to a homeless person. The prison declined

852.text:
his request but across Tennessee, thousands
of dollars of pizza were donated to shelters

858.text:
on his behalf by good-willed individuals.
Next up, well … more down actually, is falling.

866.text:
It may be surprising to hear that falling
is the second most lethal accident after vehicle

872.text:
collisions and, one study has claimed, that
it accounts for a whopping 35% of all accident

880.text:
and emergency visits. Your average emergency
doctor’s day is probably a couple of heart

886.text:
attacks, a stroke, a kid who swallowed pen
lid and then someone who fell off a roof,

891.text:
horse, ladder, climbing frame or palm tree.
If it’s the last one then it’s probably

896.text:
Keith Richards, you don’t need to treat
him, he’s clearly invincible.

900.text:
So who leads the way? Well in the red corner,
soon to be the black and blue corner probably,

905.text:
we have the Titan of Tumbles, the Prince of
Plummeting…it’s Zambia!

910.text:
It’s very difficult to get exact data on
this but it seems like the southern African

915.text:
nation is the falling capital, with a death
rate of 46 per 100,000. There’s a combination

923.text:
of factors here that could be the reason behind
this. Obviously, a lack of great medical facilities

928.text:
will always increase the mortality rate, as
we’ve seen with many of the other examples

932.text:
today. But maybe there is something about
the geography of Zambia that adds to it. It’s

939.text:
mostly a high plateau and there are a series
of hills, such as the Mafinga Hills that are

945.text:
difficult to cross by car so you’ll get
more people climbing on foot through difficult

950.text:
terrain.
It’s also home to one of the seven natural

953.text:
wonders of the world; Victoria Falls. And
fall you will, on occasion, if you are one

960.text:
of the few brave tourists to take a dip in
the world’s most dangerous pool.

965.text:
Devil’s pool is a natural dell in the rock
that occurs right on the very lip of the tumbling

971.text:
water. Around August to January, the flow
of the river is quiet enough so that the natural

976.text:
rock edge of the pool will keep you from being
hurled over the waterfall. But, accidents

982.text:
have been known to happen so obey the rules
of the pool; that’s no bombing, no running

987.text:
and no heavy petting.
Strangely, as dangerous as it looks, you’re

992.text:
more likely to be one of the many people who
die each year, falling out of bed – around

996.text:
500 annually in the US alone. Turns out that
falling dream is pretty

1003.text:
We turn now to a very small country in the
Himalayan Mountains, with a population of

1008.text:
just over 700,000. It is the beautiful kingdom
of Bhutan. It’s not easy to visit, they

1015.text:
strictly control tourist numbers and there
is a daily fee of $250 that you have to pay,

1023.text:
although it includes your trips and hotel.
So what is the killer here, I bet you are

1027.text:
wondering; exhaustion from all the climbing?
Some kind of goat attack?

1032.text:
The answer is actually… poisoning. At 36
per 100,000, it is some way ahead of the rest

1039.text:
of the world, since everyone else except New
Guinea is under 10 per 100,000.

1044.text:
Due to a lack of regulation, Bhutan has allowed
a high quantity of heavy metals, such as chromium

1051.text:
and manganese, to simply be flushed into the
local water supply after experiments and so

1056.text:
on. This is especially odd as the country
is famous for being one of the world’s leading

1063.text:
environmentally focused places. I guess they
never thought of it as a problem, whereas

1068.text:
in many industrial nations, there is a long
history of poisonings to look back at. Chromium,

1074.text:
for example, was famously what contaminated
the town of Hinkley, California, and caused

1080.text:
noticeably higher rates of cancer, covered
in the Julia Roberts film Erin Brockovich.

1086.text:
More recently, the lead poisonings in Flint,
Michigan, show that we never know when the

1091.text:
water might go bad.
It was actually a lead poisoning that put

1096.text:
Bhutan in the news a few years back. A man
in Switzerland was diagnosed with heavy metal

1101.text:
poisoning and they found that on his frequent
trips to Bhutan, he had been taking an alternative

1107.text:
medicine and the pills were covered in a red
paint, high in lead.

1112.text:
The man was hoping to cure his condition of
Bell’s palsy, a type of face paralysis.

1117.text:
He was told the pills contained the hair of
a dead Bhutanese priest but when they were

1123.text:
analysed, no trace was found. I personally,
prefer my medicine without a dead man’s

1128.text: fringe in it, but each to their own, I guess.

1131.text:
And finally, one of the most First World Problems
I’ve ever come across.

1137.text:
The USA leads the planet for a truly heroic
way to go. Averaging two embarrassing funerals

1144.text:
per year, it’s the country where you are
most likely to be crushed to death by a vending

1149.text:
machine. At least there’ll be plenty of
snacks at the wake.

1153.text:
So, the world might be a dangerous place sometimes
but let’s not all get too paranoid. Life

1160.text:
expectancy keeps on creeping up and you’ll
probably end up living far longer than you

1164.text:
wanted to anyway. You might still be around
for series 49 of Games of Thrones. For those

1169.text:
of you that have managed to stay alive all
the way through this video, well done and

1174.text: thanks for the view, subscribe for more Thoughty2.
